questions.prompt: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for routing packets between networks?
questions.explanation: The Network Layer (Layer 3) handles logical addressing and routing packets across different networks using protocols like IP.

questions.prompt: What is the primary difference between a hub and a switch?
options: Switches broadcast to all ports, hubs forward selectively
Switches forward frames selectively based on MAC addresses, hubs broadcast to all ports
Hubs operate at Layer 3, switches at Layer 2
questions.explanation: Switches learn MAC addresses and forward frames only to the appropriate port, while hubs simply broadcast all traffic to every port.

questions.prompt: The TCP/IP model has fewer layers than the OSI model.
questions.explanation: The TCP/IP model has 4 layers (Application, Transport, Internet, Network Access), while the OSI model has 7 layers.

questions.prompt: The process of adding header information as data moves down the protocol stack is called ____.
questions.explanation: Encapsulation is the process where each layer adds its own header (and sometimes trailer) to the data from the layer above.

questions.prompt: Which organization is responsible for developing Internet standards through RFCs?
questions.explanation: The Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) develops Internet standards and publishes them as Request for Comments (RFCs).

questions.prompt: At which OSI layer does a router operate?
questions.explanation: Routers operate at Layer 3 (Network Layer) because they make forwarding decisions based on IP addresses.

questions.prompt: In the TCP/IP model, which layer would handle the HTTP protocol?
questions.codeSnippet:
Layer 4: Application
Layer 3: Transport (TCP/UDP)
Layer 2: Internet (IP)
Layer 1: Network Access
questions.explanation: HTTP is an application layer protocol in the TCP/IP model, handling web communication between clients and servers.

questions.prompt: What type of network spans a city or metropolitan area?
questions.explanation: A Metropolitan Area Network (MAN) spans a city or large campus, larger than a LAN but smaller than a WAN.

questions.prompt: A MAC address is 32 bits long.
questions.explanation: A MAC address is 48 bits (6 bytes) long, typically written as six pairs of hexadecimal digits (e.g., AA:BB:CC:DD:EE:FF).

questions.prompt: Which network device creates separate collision domains for each port?
questions.explanation: A switch creates a separate collision domain for each port, unlike a hub which shares one collision domain across all ports.
802.3 is the IEEE standard for Ethernet. 802.11 is Wi-Fi, 802.15 is Bluetooth, and 802.1 covers bridging and network management.

questions.prompt: In packet switching, what happens to data before transmission?
options: Data is divided into packets that travel independently
Data is transmitted as a continuous stream
Bandwidth is reserved for the entire session
questions.explanation: In packet switching, data is broken into packets that can take different paths through the network and be reassembled at the destination.

questions.prompt: The first 3 bytes (24 bits) of a MAC address identify the ____ (vendor/manufacturer).
questions.explanation: The OUI (Organizationally Unique Identifier) is assigned by IEEE to manufacturers and identifies the vendor of the network interface.

questions.prompt: The OSI model was developed after the TCP/IP model but is more commonly used in actual Internet implementations.
questions.explanation: While OSI was developed to be the standard, TCP/IP was already in use and became the de facto Internet protocol. OSI serves mainly as a reference model.

questions.prompt: Which layer is responsible for end-to-end communication and port addressing?
questions.explanation: The Transport Layer (Layer 4) provides end-to-end communication between applications using port numbers to identify processes.
